awd_titl_txt: Marine Sediment Sampling Facility (MARSSAM) Oceanographic Instrumentation:  Acquisition of a Vibracorer
awd_abstract_narration:
The Marine Sediments Sampling Group (MARSSAM) located at Oregon State University requests funds for the purchase of a vibracore system. MARSSAM provides the full gamut of coring services to the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) community, from surface sampling to piston cores of up to ~25 m in length. MARSSAM coordinates with principal investigators (PIs) with research cruise time supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and other federal agencies, determining what equipment is necessary for the accomplishment of scientific goals, and ensuring that equipment is compatible with vessel capabilities. Central to this mandate, MARSSAM adapts coring technology to the vessels of the Academic Research Fleet (ARF) requested by science PIs so that they can recover the sediments needed for their research. MARSSAM designs, maintains, and rebuilds coring equipment, supervising coring and meta-data collection at sea, and training the science party in the collection of shipboard physical properties data and core splitting.  MARSSAM technicians also provide logistical support needed to cycle coring gear to and from globally distributed research vessels as well as to return cores to NSF marine geology archives post cruise.

Vibracoring System	$126,222	
							
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sediments accumulating on the ocean floor contain environmental histories reflecting the conditions under which they were deposited. There are a variety of methods for sampling the seafloor, but for studies focused on reconstructions extending back centuries to millennia the most common methods involve sediment coring. Vibracorers are a type of corer consisting of a vibrating corehead, typically powered by an eccentric cam which causes a large mass at the top of the corer to shake, creating localized liquifaction around the core pipe and driving the core pipe into the sediment. These systems are typically the most effective, and sometimes the only effective, way of sampling sandy and/or heterogenous sediments – characterizing a wide range of environments of significant research interest, ranging from storm and earthquake deposits to sediments deposited by retreating marine-terminating glaciers. This proposal was for the acquisition of a vibracoring system by the Oregon State University Marine Rock and Sediment Sampling (MARSSAM) Facility, which provides logistical and shipboard support for NSF-funded researchers from across the country who require samples of the seafloor. The proposal grew from recurrent requests from NSF-funded researchers in need of this instrument, and it is already seeing significant use aboard the US Academic Research Fleet. Prior to the acquisition of this capability by MARSSAM, only PI's who had a vibracorer on their individual inventories were able to access this technology without budgeting for (significantly expensive) equipment rental. Availability of a vibracorer through the MARSSAM facility puts this technology and the sediments it samples within reach of any seagoing NSF-supported PI, with disproportionate benefit to those in earlier career stages and at smaller institutions.
